sub_topic: Finding the phase shift of trigonometric functions
message_1: A sine function has a phase shift of 30 degrees to the left and an amplitude of 2. If the equation of the function is y = 2sin(2x - 30), what is the period of the function?
message_2:
To find the period of the sine function, we need to look at the coefficient of the x term inside the sine function. In this case, the coefficient is 2. The general formula for the period of a sine function is:

Period = (2π) / |B|

where B is the coefficient of the x term. In this case, B = 2. So, the period of the function is:

Period = (2π) / |2| = (2π) / 2 = π

The period of the function y = 2sin(2x - 30) is π.
